metadata.title: Excel Society Website Redesign
metadata.description: A redesign of Excel Society’s website focused on improving usability, accessibility, and improved staff content management.

projectSummary.description: In collaboration with Excel Society and the work-integrated learning platform |Ripen|, we built a responsive website in Webflow that enables staff to manage content easily and helps users find services, events, and other essential information through accessible and well-organized design.
projectSummary.role: I collaborated on UX research, wireframing and design. I also played a major role in front and backend development tasks, including implementing CMS structures, building responsive layouts, and implementing JavaScript using Webflow and third-party tools.

contents.text: A website often serves as the first point of contact for organizations that rely on public support and community engagement. It's not just a source of information, as it's where people decide whether to get involved, seek services, or offer support. The website's various needs mean accommodating a wide range of users; however, each group brings different goals and digital expectations. The challenge lies in designing an experience that communicates and adapts to varied needs.

items.text: The large blocks of text can potentially overwhelm the user and a lack of clear pathways to donate, volunteer, or participate results in low interaction rates and missed opportunities.

items.header: Unclear Communication of Mission and Services
items.text: The website does not clearly explain who Excel Society is or what they do. This lack of clarity limits user engagement and reduces understanding of their services.

items.header: Outdated System with Limited Update Flexibility
items.text: The site is built on a system that requires a developer to update content. This prevents staff from easily posting new information about events or services.

contents.text: Working collaboratively, my team completely redesigned the website using a modern, responsive platform to address usability and maintenance challenges. Essential improvements included:

items.text: Navigation was restructured, using user-centred categories and moving pages into their respective sections.
The new design emphasized accessibility and clarity, with streamlined content, strong visual hierarchy, and high-visibility calls to action.
Webflow's content management system was implemented to allow staff to update events, news, and program details directly through a user-friendly dashboard, reducing reliance on developers.
A dedicated events page with filtering options and clearly placed volunteer and contact links were introduced to make participation and support more visible.

contents.text: The original Excel Society website presented major usability and maintenance issues for its primary audiences, including supporters, clients, and volunteers. We conducted a client interview, a card-sorting exercise, and a comprehensive content audit to uncover these issues.

quotes: The current website is pretty outdated, so we're totally open to new ideas and changes.
We want to grow our events page and make it super easy to update
We’re hoping more people get involved, like by working with us, volunteering, or donating.
We’re open to changing the wording to make it feel more inclusive and welcoming to everyone.

contents.statement: As a volunteer, I want to quickly find relevant information about services and events so that I can stay engaged and support the organization.

contents.text: During this phase, I worked with my team to reimagine Excel Society's web experience, structure and design based on our findings and strategic insights. I contributed to the following with the help of my team:

items.header: Reorganized Content for Clarity and Navigation
items.text: We restructured the sitemap to reduce redundancy and grouped related content to help users find essential information more quickly.
Drawing from our prototyping and feedback, we developed a clean and approachable design system aligned with Excel Society's mission and audience.

items.header: Prioritized Accessibility and Ease of Maintenance
items.text: We designed the site to be responsive, accessible, and easy for staff to update, ensuring long-term usability without requiring technical expertise.

contents.text: To bring our redesigned concept to life, we followed a structured development process using the MAST framework to simplify building grids and encourage creating and using reusable classes. While the entire team collaborated on structuring and styling pages, I primarily handled advanced interactions, JavaScript functionality, and managing structured content systems.

items.text: We redefined how content was organized and connected across the site, using CMS collections for easy updates and ensuring scalability, consistency, and logical relationships between services, events, and news.
We created reusable components to maintain visual consistency and streamline future updates across the site.
Every page was developed to be fully responsive across desktop, tablet, and mobile, ensuring accessibility and usability for a broad audience of guardians, donors, and clients.

Webflow lacked built-in support for complex user interactions like dynamic content filtering with their databases.

|Solution:| I helped implement conditional logic through structured CMS collections and integrated third-party tools like Finsweet to enable advanced filtering and interactivity.

Webflow's visual editor required extra care to uphold accessibility standards, such as semantic HTML and alt text on images.

|Solution:| We performed manual audits during development and used tools like Webflow's audit panel to meet WCAG compliance.

Many original pages had inconsistent formatting and excessive text, making direct migration inefficient.

|Solution:| We rewrote and restructured some of the content during implementation to fit the new visual hierarchy and break dense blocks into skimmable, sectioned layouts.

contents.text: This project reinforced the importance of thoughtful content architecture and inclusive design—especially for nonprofits serving diverse users like donors, guardians, and clients. We delivered a welcoming, manageable, mission-aligned site by combining accessibility-first thinking with clear user pathways.

items.header: Client collaboration anchored every design choice
items.text: Early interviews and strategy sessions helped us stay aligned with Excel Society's vision and build a site that truly supports their goals which allows for connection, clarity, and ease of use.

items.header: Balancing clarity with complexity was key
items.text: Many pages required presenting dense information, so we tried different layout strategies like visual hierarchy, sectioning, and skimmable formatting to keep content digestible without oversimplifying.

items.header: Starting from Problem Discovery to Development
items.text: From identifying usability issues through research to restructuring the content and implementing a maintainable site, our team worked iteratively to ensure every phase was built toward a solution that met user and client needs.
